answer:
My name is Nayan Reddy Soma, and I’m a data enthusiast with a strong foundation in analytics, data visualization, and automation. I recently completed my Bachelor's in Computer Science and Engineering, with a specialization in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning.

Over the past few years, I’ve applied these skills through hands-on projects. One of the most impactful was building an interactive Expense Tracking System using Python (FastAPI), MySQL, and Streamlit. I implemented a session-based architecture so each user gets a private, real-time analytical view of their expenses.

I also developed a full-scale Power BI project called Business 360, where I worked with 1.8M+ rows of data from both offline and online retail channels. I designed a snowflake schema, created advanced DAX measures, and built six dashboard pages tailored to Finance, Sales, Marketing, Supply Chain, and Executive stakeholders.

Across my projects, I’ve worked with over 3.5 million rows of data and covered domains like finance, operations, and consumer behavior. I’m confident with tools like Power BI, SQL, Python (especially Pandas), and Excel, and I’m passionate about turning raw data into meaningful business insights. I’m now looking to join a team where I can keep growing as a data analyst and contribute to solving real-world challenges. You can checkout my Portfolio here [Portfolio](https://codebasics.io/portfolio/Nayan-Reddy-Soma)

answer:
I’m highly comfortable with Power BI, SQL, Excel, and Python — these are the core tools I’ve used to deliver real, impactful solutions in my projects.

In Power BI, I’ve worked with the complete reporting stack: from Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) using Power Query, to advanced data modeling, DAX, row-level security, bookmarks, parameters, and report optimization. My Business 360 Dashboard project, for example, involved over 1.8 million rows and required deep performance tuning.

With SQL, I handle data extraction, aggregation, and transformation using window functions, joins, CTEs, subqueries, and set operations — ensuring efficient querying and clean, analysis-ready data.

In Advanced Excel, I use pivot tables, dynamic arrays, Power Query, Power Pivot, charts, and conditional formatting to create highly interactive and flexible dashboards, especially when building solutions for standalone use or quick business analysis.

Python is another tool I’ve used for automation and analytics — working with libraries like pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib, Seaborn, and even scikit-learn for basic predictive modeling and exploratory data analysis.

Beyond tools, I apply business analytics principles like KPI tracking, forecasting, and financial modeling to make sure my insights actually support decision-making and business strategy.

answer:
My data workflow usually starts by understanding the business problem — I believe it’s crucial to know *why* we’re analyzing the data before diving in. Once that's clear, I gather data through SQL queries, APIs, or file uploads, depending on the source.

Next comes cleaning and transformation using tools like Python (Pandas), Power Query, or SQL. After that, I model the data — building relationships, aggregations, and calculated columns or measures to prepare it for analysis.

I then design the final output, usually in Power BI or Excel, with a focus on clarity and usability for the end user. I also make it a point to document the process and version-control any important logic, especially when working with DAX or Python scripts.

The goal is always to create something that not only looks good but also tells a story backed by reliable data.

answer:
I first assess the extent and nature of the missing or messy data — whether it's due to user input, source system issues, or merging mismatched schemas. Then I choose the right approach:

• If the data is critical, I might use imputation or external references to fill gaps.
• If it's non-critical, I may exclude it to preserve accuracy.
• In case of structural issues, I clean the data using Python (Pandas), Power Query, or SQL with CASE/NULL handling.

I always document my choices and communicate any assumptions to avoid misinterpretation downstream.

answer:
One of my favorites is a custom Profit & Loss SWITCH() measure I wrote for my Power BI dashboard. It used the order of each P&L row to calculate different metrics — like Net Sales, COGS, GM%, and Net Profit % — within the same dynamic measure.

This helped me reduce complexity, ensure consistency across visuals, and support parameter-driven comparisons like actual vs. budget or year-over-year views.

DAX can get tricky with context, but when used right, it allows powerful control over dynamic reporting.

As of now, I’m in the early stages of my career and don’t have formal work experience in a full-time professional setting. However, I’ve worked extensively on practical, real-world data analytics projects to develop and showcase my expertise.

Here are some highlights of my experience through projects:

1. My main project is this AI Assistant you're interacting with now. I engineered it as a full-stack application with a strong **data analytics** component at its core. A key feature is the **live analytics dashboard** I built, which tracks and visualizes user engagement and my own performance in real-time.

This project showcases my ability to handle a complete project lifecycle—from designing a complex AI system to deploying it and, most importantly, analyzing its performance through data. [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/Nayan-chatbot)

2. Power BI Expertise: Built a Business 360 Dashboard analyzing 1.8 million rows of sales and marketing data. It involved advanced DAX measures, ETL processes, and creating industry-standard visuals for stakeholders. The dashboard provided actionable insights on sales trends, profitability, and marketing ROI.
[View Dashboard](https://app.powerbi.com/view?r=eyJrIjoiYzFkZGY3NGUtMWIwYy00YjZmLWIzMDYtYjQyMjkxNGRhN2NmIiwidCI6ImM2ZTU0OWIzLTVmNDUtNDAzMi1hYWU5LWQ0MjQ0ZGM1YjJjNCJ9) [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/Business-Insights).

3. Python & Web Development: Built an Expense Tracker Application using FastAPI, Streamlit, and MySQL. It’s a fully functional app for personal finance management, complete with analytics dashboards, interactive charts, and automated user authentication.
[Try the App](https://expense-tracker-frontend-nayan-reddy.streamlit.app/) [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/expense-tracker-frontend).

4. SQL: The Consumer Goods project was an in-depth SQL challenge where I acted as a data analyst for an FMCG company. The goal was to solve 10 critical, real-world business problems by translating ad-hoc requests from management into actionable data insights.
Using MySQL, I wrote a series of complex queries to address questions related to:

* **Market & Sales Performance:** Identifying top-performing products and analyzing weekly sales growth.
* **Customer Insights:** Calculating Customer Lifetime Value (LTV) and performing cohort analysis to understand retention.
* **Supply Chain:** Evaluating supplier on-time performance and managing inventory levels. [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/Consumer-goods)

5. Advanced Excel: Designed division-level and category-level sales dashboards with slicers, trend analysis, and KPIs for business insights and reporting.
[Explore Excel Project](https://1drv.ms/x/c/e4ca29151a0a4ec4/EeJ0-_SJhOZIjam0emzh_ccBfDKFeWhL2IMsVI7DXtXB0Q?e=jisfwq)

answer:
I believe the key to effective communication is empathy and simplification. Whenever I work with non-technical stakeholders, I first focus on understanding their goals, not the tools. Once I know what decisions they need to make, I tailor my explanations to match their perspective — avoiding jargon like “DAX” or “joins” and instead focusing on outcomes like “sales increased 15% in the south region” or “this category had unusually high returns.”

For example, in my Power BI dashboard (Business 360), I created separate views for executives, finance, marketing, and supply chain — each with tailored KPIs and plain-language tooltips, so anyone could understand the insights at a glance without needing to know how the backend worked.

In short, I always aim to translate data into decisions, not just reports.

answer:
📊 **Power BI Project – Business 360 Dashboard**

My Power BI project is titled **“Business 360 Dashboard”**, a comprehensive business intelligence solution designed to analyze and visualize data across core business domains like Sales, Marketing, Finance, Supply Chain, and Executive Strategy.

🔗 **View Live Dashboard:** [Power BI Business 360 Dashboard](https://app.powerbi.com/view?r=eyJrIjoiYzFkZGY3NGUtMWIwYy00YjZmLWIzMDYtYjQyMjkxNGRhN2NmIiwidCI6ImM2ZTU0OWIzLTVmNDUtNDAzMi1hYWU5LWQ0MjQ0ZGM1YjJjNCJ9) [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/Business-Insights)

---

### 🧭 **Overview of the Project**

The Business 360 Dashboard simulates the operations of a real company using **1.8M+ rows of data**. It provides a bird’s-eye view of company performance, with drill-downs into specific departments or KPIs.

---

### 📌 **Department-Level Analysis**
  
- The **Financial View** displays P&L metrics like Gross Sales, Net Invoice Sales, Operating Costs, GM%, and Net Profit across a matrix  
- The **Sales View** segmented performance by product and customer, using Gross Margin % and Net Sales as core KPIs.  
- The **Marketing View** compared Category and Segment performance and calculated Net Profit % using dynamic DAX.  
- The **Supply Chain View** focused on Forecast Accuracy, Net Error %, and Risk classification (e.g., Out-of-Stock or Excess Inventory).  
- The **Executive View** highlighted market share (including AtliQ's Market Share), RC%, and a top-level business summary with dynamic toggling between dimensions.

---

### 🧩 **Key Features**

1️⃣ **Dynamic Slicers & Drill-Downs** – Users can slice data by region, product, year, or customer segment and drill into granular details.  
2️⃣ **Geographic Insights** – Location-based revenue heatmaps and regional KPIs.  
3️⃣ **Advanced KPIs** – Net sales, gross margin, profit %, YoY growth, forecast error, etc.  
4️⃣ **Custom DAX Measures** – Rolling averages, profitability ratios, and more.  
5️⃣ **Interactive Visualizations** – Tree maps, bar charts, KPIs, scatter plots, custom tooltips.

---

### 🧮 **Data Modeling & Schema**

Built on a **snowflake schema (18 interconnected tables which includes 6 fact tables)**:  
- **Fact Tables:** Sales, actuals, forecasts etc.  
- **Dimension Tables:** Products, customers, regions, time, channels, discounts, expense etc.  
ETL handled in Power Query: null handling, type corrections, filtering.

---

### ⚙️ **Tech Stack & Tools**

- **Power BI Desktop** – Visual dashboard creation.  
- **Power Query** – Data cleansing and transformation.  
- **DAX** – Custom KPIs, calculated columns, time intelligence.

---

The entire project was designed not just for data presentation, but for enabling **strategic decision-making** — giving a unified view of how each department contributes to the organization’s goals.

If you want to dive deeper into any part of the project — like **DAX measures**, **forecast analysis**, or **data modeling techniques** — feel free to ask! 😊

questions: What kind of data model did you use in your Power BI project?
Was it a star or snowflake schema?
Why did you choose a snowflake schema?
Explain the data model behind your Business 360 dashboard
How did you structure your Power BI data schema?
answer:
For my Business 360 Power BI dashboard, I used a **snowflake schema** for the data model. This approach normalized the dimension tables to reduce redundancy and improve maintainability. It allowed for better granularity, especially when slicing data across divisions, categories, customer segments, and time periods.

The model consisted of a central **fact table with over 1.8 million rows**, representing actuals, estimates, and market share data. Surrounding it were multiple dimension tables like `dim_date`, `dim_customer`, `dim_market`, and `dim_product`, which were further normalized to support accurate drilldowns and interlinked KPIs.

This schema helped maintain data integrity and supported advanced DAX queries efficiently. It was particularly useful for performance tuning and complex cross-functional analysis across Sales, Finance, Supply Chain, and Marketing.

questions: What kind of DAX measures did you write?
How did you handle calculations in Power BI?
Did you use DAX?
Tell me about the KPIs or calculations you created
What were the most complex DAX formulas you used?
answer:
Yes, I used **extensive DAX** to drive most of the business logic and KPIs across the dashboard. Each page had purpose-specific DAX measures.

For example, in the **Financial View**, I built a dynamic Profit & Loss matrix using DAX logic like `SWITCH(TRUE())` to calculate values based on row order — including Gross Sales, Net Sales, GM%, Net Profit %, and Chg% compared to baselines.

In the **Marketing View**, I created a performance matrix with parameter toggles to compare `GM %` vs `Net Profit %`, and calculated variances using DAX expressions like `Δ NP % = DIVIDE([Net Profit %], [NP % BM], 0) - 1`.

In the **Supply Chain View**, I implemented `Forecast Accuracy %` and `Net Error %` using DAX logic with nested `SUMX` and `DISTINCT` to evaluate performance across months and products.

Across the project, I used DAX features like **calculated columns**, **measure groups**, **dynamic parameters**, **row context**, **HASONEVALUE**, and **context transition** to create a rich analytical layer.

The **Financial View** in my Power BI dashboard simulates a full **Profit and Loss statement** using a dynamic matrix powered by DAX. It includes Gross Sales, Pre/Post Invoice Deductions, Net Invoice Sales, COGS, GM %, Operational Expenses, and Net Profit %.

This view is especially valuable for finance teams or business heads to analyze profitability drivers and cost structures across different dimensions.

The **Supply Chain View** helps evaluate the accuracy of sales forecasts and identify inventory risks. I calculated **Forecast Accuracy %**, **Net Error %**, and **Risk Classification (OOS/EI)** using advanced DAX with `SUMX`, `DISTINCT`, and nested expressions.

questions: Can you show me a SQL query using GROUP BY?
Group by
group by function
Have you written any query that shows yearly sales trends?
How did you analyze sales division wise in your SQL project?
answer:
Absolutely. Here's one of the queries I wrote to analyze YoY sales growth by product division:

```sql
SELECT
    p.division,
    EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date) AS sales_year,
    ROUND(SUM(s.gross_sales_amount), 2) AS total_sales
FROM
    fact_sales s
JOIN
    dim_product p ON s.product_id = p.product_id
GROUP BY
    p.division, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date)
ORDER BY
    p.division, sales_year;
```

This helped us compare yearly sales performance across different divisions. 

There are more if you would like to explore - RANK functions, WINDOW functions, Sales Drop, JOINs, and ROUND. Just ask and the query would be presented 😊

answer:
Yes! Here's a query using `RANK()` and window function to find the top 3 performing channels per year:

```sql
WITH channel_yearly_sales AS (
  SELECT
    c.channel,
    EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date) AS sales_year,
    SUM(s.gross_sales_amount) AS total_sales
  FROM
    fact_sales s
  JOIN
    dim_customer c ON s.customer_id = c.customer_id
  GROUP BY
    c.channel, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date)
)
SELECT *
FROM (
  SELECT *,
         RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY sales_year ORDER BY total_sales DESC) AS rank
  FROM channel_yearly_sales
) ranked_channels
WHERE rank <= 3;
```

This helped business stakeholders focus on consistently high-performing channels.

There are more if you would like to explore - Group by, Sales Drop, JOINs, and ROUND. Just ask and the query would be presented 😊

questions: Can you show a query that identifies sales drop?
sales drop
How did you find underperforming products?
Have you written comparison queries in SQL?
answer:
Yes, I created a query that detects products with decreasing sales year-over-year. Here's the SQL:

```sql
WITH sales_by_product_year AS (
  SELECT
    p.product_id,
    p.product_name,
    EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date) AS sales_year,
    SUM(s.gross_sales_amount) AS total_sales
  FROM
    fact_sales s
  JOIN
    dim_product p ON s.product_id = p.product_id
  GROUP BY
    p.product_id, p.product_name, EXTRACT(YEAR FROM s.order_date)
)
SELECT
  a.product_name,
  a.total_sales AS sales_2020,
  b.total_sales AS sales_2021,
  ROUND(((b.total_sales - a.total_sales) / a.total_sales) * 100, 2) AS percent_change
FROM
  sales_by_product_year a
JOIN
  sales_by_product_year b ON a.product_id = b.product_id AND a.sales_year = 2020 AND b.sales_year = 2021
WHERE
  b.total_sales < a.total_sales
ORDER BY percent_change ASC;
```

It helped identify which products needed more attention.

There are more if you would like to explore - Group by, RANK functions, WINDOW functions, JOINs, and ROUND. Just ask and the query would be presented 😊

SELECT

        (SELECT SUM(gross_sales_amount) FROM fact_sales), 2) AS contribution_pct
FROM

questions: Have you used SWITCH in DAX?
How did you handle dynamic matrix or row logic?
Show me a complex DAX expression you’ve written
answer:
Yes, I used `SWITCH(TRUE())` to dynamically populate P&L values in matrix visuals. Here’s the actual DAX formula:

```DAX
P & L values = 
VAR res = SWITCH(
    TRUE(),
    MAX('P & L Rows'[Order]) = 1, [GS $]/1000000,
    MAX('P & L Rows'[Order]) = 2, [Pre Invoice Deduction $]/1000000,
    MAX('P & L Rows'[Order]) = 3, [NIS $]/1000000,
    MAX('P & L Rows'[Order]) = 4, [Post Invoice Deduction $]/1000000,
    ...
)
RETURN IF(HASONEVALUE('P & L Rows'[Description]), res, [NS $]/1000000)
```

This allowed flexible rendering of financial data in a structured matrix layout.

What is the architecture of Nayan's AI assistant?
answer:
I am that project! I'm a full-stack AI assistant built to serve as an interactive portfolio.

The core of my system is an advanced **Hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)** pipeline. When you ask a question, I first use semantic search to find the most accurate answer from a knowledge base. If that's not a perfect match, I use fuzzy matching as a backup. Only if neither can answer do I fall back on a generative model (GPT-4o).

To ensure our conversations stay on topic, I have **'Intelligent Guardrails'** built with **spaCy** for Named Entity Recognition. This helps me recognize and filter out-of-scope or sensitive questions.

From a technical perspective, my frontend is built with **Streamlit**, and the entire backend logic is in Python. One of my key features is a **real-time analytics pipeline** that logs user interactions to a Google Sheet, which then feeds a live dashboard to visualize my performance and user engagement. You can explore the complete source code on GitHub. [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Nayan-Reddy/Nayan-chatbot) [Analytics Dashboard](https://nayan-chatbot-analytics.streamlit.app/)
